item.title: Dyson Quietly Clears Out the Supersonic, Salon-Grade Hair Dryer Now Going for Peanuts
item.content:encoded:
Dyson built its reputation on mastering airflow in vacuum cleaners so jumping into hair dryers might seem like an odd pivot until you realize it‚Äôs the exact same engineering challenge. The Supersonic Origin applies that airflow expertise to drying hair faster and with less heat damage than traditional dryers that basically just blast hot air at your head.

Right now, Amazon has dropped this powerful tool to $299, down from its usual $419 price, which marks an all-time low for a device that rarely sees discounts. If you‚Äôve been frustrated with frizzy results or spending 20 minutes blow-drying your hair, this deal makes switching to professional-grade technology affordable.

See at Amazon

What Makes the Supersonic Different From Your Average Dryer

The Supersonic Origin places the motor at the handle instead of the head and entirely alters the balance and handling. Classic hair dryers place a cumbersome motor at the top and cause your arm to tire within minutes and producing that unpleasant weight distribution. Dyson‚Äôs V9 digital motor rotates at 110,000 rpm which is ridiculously quick next to standard dryers that top at 20,000 rpm. The fast motor drives 13 liters per second through the barrel and produces a concentrated, high-velocity airbeam that dries hair internally, not roasting the top.

Its smart heat control system takes air temperature readings 40 times per second and transmits the readings to a microprocessor that controls the heating element. The result is that the air temperature never goes above 302¬∞F and that‚Äôs important because hair damage takes off at a very rapid rate above that temperature. Drugstore dryers are not very temperature-controlled at all and can easily reach 350-400¬∞F and they fry the protective cuticle layer on your hair. The Supersonic controls temperatures evenly, so your hair dries fast without the crispy, damaged feel that so often comes from the intense heat.

This Supersonic model comes with the necessary attachments that will suit the majority of daily styling requirements. The concentrator for styling allows for a focused airflow for smooth and controlled drying and is ideal when using a round brush to add volume. The wide tooth comb attachment is ideal for hair that is coily, curly, or highly textured, and enables curl drying and lengthening at the same time without interfering with the natural form. The diffused air attachment is for fine hair or sensitive scalps that cannot tolerate strong direct heat.

These are actual airflow and heat settings, not the typical low-medium-high. You get three real speed settings with four heat settings and a cold shot button that sets your style with the closure of the cuticle on your hair. The cold shot is not a gimmick: it seals the hydrogen bonds of your hair at the completion of heat styling, and your blowout will last longer.

The acoustic engineering deserves mention because loud hair dryers are genuinely annoying, especially if you‚Äôre drying your hair early in the morning with roommates or family around. Dyson tuned the motor frequency to an inaudible pitch and then added acoustic silencers to further reduce noise. The result measures at 79 decibels which is noticeably quieter than most professional dryers that scream at 85-90 decibels. That 6-10 decibel difference translates to roughly half the perceived loudness, making the experience far more pleasant.

Right now, you‚Äôre paying roughly three times the price of an entry-level dryer at $299 but the technology is so good that it‚Äôs really worth it.

item.title: Damn, It Feels So Good To Have Ninja Gaiden Back
item.content:encoded:
What do you want out of a modern, big-budget, blockbuster video game? Large, detailed environments to explore? Tons of skill trees, crafting systems, and resources to manage? An HBO-worthy story with top-notch voice acting that keeps you playing until the end? Ninja Gaiden 4 does not give a fuck about any of these things.

Ninja Gaiden 4 is here to serve you up tense, twitchy combo-based action and flashy but simple backdrops for ever more ridiculous boss fights and bloodbaths. Nothing more. Nothing less. It gets that job done with S-tier style and attention to detail. Everything else is‚Ä¶fine. I hope that doesn‚Äôt sound like a disappointment.

It‚Äôs not. I‚Äôm 10 hours into Team Ninja and Platinum Games‚Äô cyberpunk-infused joint entry in the long-running series and I‚Äôve been loving every no-frills moment. The sequel is out October 20 on PS5, Xbox Series X/S, and PC (published by Microsoft and available day-one on Game Pass Ultimate) and my full review won‚Äôt be out until later this week. I‚Äôll leave more of my nitpicks until then. For now I can confidentially say this game has some real juice.

Ninja Gaiden 4 is the Brazilian steakhouse where the hosts keep plopping down increasingly rich and tasty hunks of meat until you feel completely gorged and then they give you more and you keep going because it‚Äôs just that good and also the world will fall to ruin at the hands of a mythic evil dragon if you don‚Äôt.

There‚Äôs not a lot of variety. You may occasionally break into a sweaty panic. But plate after plate of bloody brawls and bone-crunching boss fights will arrive and you will not send them back because this is Team Ninja‚Äôs house and you will feast until it‚Äôs over because who knows, it could be another 13 years until the next Ninja Gaiden arrives.

If you haven‚Äôt been keeping up, Ninja Gaiden 4 puts you in the shoes of Ryu Hayabusa‚Äôs rival Yakumo who wields the Bloodraven Form technique to chain the blood of his enemies into dazzling and devastating combo attacks (you also play as Ryu in some chapters). Yakumo gets access to multiple weapons with different attack patterns and unlockable move sets. There‚Äôs even an ultimate meter you can fill up to unleash quick executions.

Combined with dodges, parries, and an overwhelming number of fighting-game-style aerial maneuvers and attacks, the combat rewards close attention and thoughtful execution. It‚Äôs a button-mashing gorefest, except that every button is pressed for a particular reason and if it‚Äôs not, you‚Äôre probably looking at the game over screen again.

Every challenge room and boss fight so far has left me feeling satisfied and accomplished in exchange for the effort expended, even when progress slowed to a crawl and it briefly felt like I was banging my head against the wall. Ninja Gaiden 4 is so limited and focused in terms of what it puts in front of you that I found these periods of stalled momentum as cathartic and calming as pushing through to the next chapter.

I won‚Äôt talk about the story because I‚Äôm not finished yet and, well, when has a Ninja Gaiden story ever really mattered that much? There‚Äôs a mysterious woman manipulating you into breaking magical seals to purify the ancient dragon and prevent it from returning to haunt neo-Tokyo. The English language dubs are not great so I‚Äôm playing with subtitles. The conversations and characters, like the spartan levels you encounter them in, provide the most barebones table setting for a linear series of battles and the occasional 3D Sonic-style platforming section.

None of the stuff outside of combat has been all that great in Ninja Gaiden 4 so far, so I welcome there being so little of it. This is a game about seeing how long you can keep your health meter unscathed while landing just enough blows to randomly sever an enemy‚Äôs limb and open them up to a grisly execution move that sprays blood all over the screen and nets you points toward your high score for the stage. It‚Äôs strikingly old-school that way. It‚Äôs nice to have you back, Ninja Gaiden.

item.title: Lay‚Äôs Says 42% Of People Didn‚Äôt Know Its Potato Chips Were Made From Actual Potatoes
item.content:encoded:
Lay‚Äôs potato chips are receiving a big rebrand that makes it clear that the popular snack food is made from potatoes. That might seem silly, until you realize that according to the chip maker, nearly half of the people who buy its product didn‚Äôt know the chips were made using potatoes. Seriously.

Earlier this month, Lay‚Äôs announced plans to ‚Äúrevamp‚Äù the ‚Äúworld‚Äôs most popular potato chip‚Äù and laid out what it intends to do in a press release that revealed the new chip bag design and shared the surprising statistic.

‚ÄúThere are more than 4,000 registered potato varieties in the world, and only 10 are good enough to become a Lay‚Äôs potato chip,‚Äù explained Lay‚Äôs in a press release that mentions the word potato nearly 30 times. ‚ÄúLay‚Äôs spends up to nine years creating the best potato for farmers to grow that can deliver the perfect crisp, flavor and golden glow when sliced and cooked. The potatoes‚Äô journey from the soil to the shelf is the heart of Lay‚Äôs. But here‚Äôs the surprising part ‚Äî 42% of people who enjoy Lay‚Äôs don‚Äôt realize they‚Äôre made with real, farm-grown potatoes.‚Äù

Usually, I find press releases to be filled with exaggerated language and brand hype that I roll my eyes at, but yeah, no, that is indeed surprising. Nearly half of the people who buy and consume Lay‚Äôs chips don‚Äôt know they are made from‚Ä¶potatoes? It makes me wonder what they thought the chips were made out of and if they even had a guess or were just buying bags of salty and crispy snacks without much thought beyond ‚ÄúIt tastes good.‚Äù

The new Lay‚Äôs chip bag

So to help address this problem, and also declining sales, the chip maker is rebranding its most famous product. I mean, this doesn‚Äôt seem like Lay‚Äôs problem to me, but it‚Äôs nice they are trying something. You‚Äôll notice that the new bag design has potatoes on it. I mean, the old design literally had a potato transforming into a chip on the front of it, but apparently that wasn‚Äôt working. The new bag looks more rustic with wood paneling artwork, and even says, in big black letters, ‚ÄúMade with real potatoes.‚Äù Lay‚Äôs really wants you all to know that these are potato chips. Lay‚Äôs also says it‚Äôs removing artificial flavors and colors from its popular potato chip brand in the United States, too. I assume this is connected to U.S. Health Secretary and America‚Äôs 14th weirdest maniac, Robert F. Kennedy Jr, and his ongoing war against artificial flavors and other chemicals he doesn‚Äôt like.

‚ÄúThe new visual identity celebrates the humble, farm-grown potato ‚Äî where every Lay‚Äôs potato chip starts ‚Äî and heroes the ingredients that deliver the unmatched flavor consumers have always loved,‚Äù explained Alexis Porter, PepsiCo‚Äôs Vice President of Marketing, Global Lay‚Äôs, in a press release. You can almost hear the desperation from Porter when talking about how these chips are made from potatoes.

Will all of this work? Who can say? It does feel like more than ever, the world is slipping into accepted stupidity, while folks seem overall less interested in learning. And if you do try to learn anything, you just end up reading AI-generated summaries filled with nonsense. Or maybe people just assume everything they buy in a store is fake and overly processed plastic pretending to be food. Probably a bit of column A and column B. I‚Äôm feeling kind of sad about the future. Seems like the perfect time to curl up on my couch and eat some chips. Wonder what these things are made out of?

item.title: Here Are The 10 Most Popular Free Demos From October‚Äôs Steam Next Fest
item.content:encoded:
The October 2025 Steam Next Fest wrapped up today and Valve has revealed the most downloaded demos from the event. Big winners included Heroes of Might and Magic: Olden Era, Everwind, and YAPYAP. If you‚Äôve never heard of any of those, this is your chance to catch up on tomorrow‚Äôs hit Steam games before they‚Äôre out.

Here are the top 10 demo downloads during the latest Steam Next Fest in order of most unique players:

  • Half Sword (medieval swordplay sim)
  • Heroes of Might and Magic: Olden Era (turn-based strategy)
  • YAPYAP (magic comedy crew-like)
  • Final Sentence (typing battle royale)
  • Reanimal (co-op horror adventure)
  • Everwind (co-op survival RPG)
  • The Midnight Walkers (zombie extraction shooter)
  • The Cube, Save Us (extraction MMO)
  • Misery (post-apocalyptic co-op survival)
  • Long Drive North: Co-Op RV Simulator (open world survival)

Online co-op and survival sims still reign supreme, though it‚Äôs nice to see Heroes of Might and Magic having a mini-breakout moment in 2025. ‚ÄúThis is the heroes game I have been waiting for ever since heroes 3,‚Äù wrote one Steam reviewer about the demo. I was never an HoMM guy growing up, but I like strategy RPGs and enjoyed what I tried of the Early Access build that came out earlier this month.

Here are some other games from the larger top 50 Next Fest demo list that caught my eye. Ultimate Sheep Raccoon is a multiplayer PVP Trials-like. Think 2D side-scrolling Mario Kart. Master of Command is a history buff‚Äôs historical strategy game that trades neat graphics for the nitty-gritty detail of regiment customization and supply line management. Cairn is an open-world atmospheric climbing sim. It looks like the indie version of Breath of the Wild meets Death Stranding. Tears of Metal is a co-op hack-and-slash roguelike. It‚Äôs giving Dynasty Warriors in the art style of Darkest Dungeon. Finally there‚Äôs Skate Story, a skateboard RPG in which you grind through a shadow realm to liberate tortured souls. I keep hearing great things.

The October 2025 Steam Next Fest may be over now, but most of these games still have free demos you can download if you want to check them out and wishlist them ahead of their launch windows. Because as we all know, Steam users don‚Äôt already have way too much to play.

item.title: Two Awesome FEAR Games Are On Sale Right Now (Oh, And FEAR 3 Is Too)
item.content:encoded:
The innovative and fondly remembered FEAR turns 20 this year, having been released on October 18, 2005. The game arrived on PC (and later PS3 and Xbox 360) as a thrilling mix of first-person-shooter gunplay and survival horror, incorporating exhilarating bullet-time mechanics and playing with your sense of reality when you least expected it. It remains a hell of a good time, with smart computer-controlled enemies and a mysterious little girl who will haunt your dreams. Its sequel, Project Origin, is a serviceable 360-era shooter with a‚Ä¶disturbing sexual assault scene at the end. As for FEAR 3, well, I‚Äôm sure someone likes it.

If you haven‚Äôt played these games or have been meaning to add them to your library, you can now grab the whole collection on Steam for just over five dollars from now until October 23, 2025, making it a perfect way to jump into these shooter/horror games in time for Halloween.

Read More: Warner Bros. Cancels Wonder Woman Game And Shuts Down Shadow Of Morder Studio

Developed by Monolith (RIP), FEAR puts you in the role of a ‚ÄúFirst Encounter Assault Recon‚Äù soldier tasked with stopping some out-of-control telepathically controlled soldiers. Along the way, you unravel the mysteries behind some warped experiments involving psychics and cloning.

The series‚Äô use of bullet time isn‚Äôt just about looking cool; it‚Äôs a pretty essential tool for overcoming some of the overwhelming forces you‚Äôre up against. And while it definitely feels powerful and awesome to use, it isn‚Äôt a get-out-of-jail-free card, especially on harder difficulties. You need to be mindful of when and how you use it.

The original remains an iconic game of the 2000s era, with a sequel that‚Äôs well worth your time if the universe speaks to you. Sadly, FEAR 3 (stylized as F3AR üôÑ) was a victim of the co-op shovelware trend that was particularly insidious during the 360 era. I do recall a handful of decent moments in some of the levels, but it‚Äôs a very skippable game if you‚Äôve had your fill by the end of FEAR 2‚Äôs DLC. Normally I wouldn‚Äôt advise anyone to buy it, but seeing as the whole series including the DLC is on sale on Steam as a package deal for a little over five bucks, I‚Äôd say it‚Äôs worth having this one in your collection to get the other, better ones. Say hi to Alma for me.
